Problem:
Investigate a signal processing system where a function \\( h(t) = e^{-\alpha t} \\) modulates an input function \\( x(t) \\) according to the convolution integral \\( y(t) = (h * x)(t) \\). \\( y(t) \\) is then analyzed at various time points t using a Fourier transform.

If the convolution \\( h * x \\) is applied to an input signal and then transformed using a Fourier transform without any additional filtering, will the resultant spectrum \\( Y(\omega) \\) differ from the Fourier transform of \\( x(t) \\) alone?
Explanation: The convolution with \\( h(t) \\) modifies the original signal \\( x(t) \\) by attenuating its components, especially fading out higher frequencies due to the exponential decay term \\( e^{-\alpha t} \\). This results in a different frequency spectrum \\( Y(\omega) \\) than what would be obtained from the Fourier transform of \\( x(t) \\) alone.
